entry.title: First Prototype of a Working Tricorder Unveiled at SXSW
entry.quote: Kaul was showing off the components of his entry in the Tricorder Xprize, the $10-million competition that requires teams to develop a sci-fi medical scanner worthy of Star Trek. Each device must be able to diagnose 15 different medical conditions and monitor vital signs for 72 hours.

entry.title: How Facebook Will Build the Connected World
entry.quote: Our plan has three parts: planetary connectivity, artificial intelligence and virtual reality.

entry.title: Google’s Hybrid Approach to Research
entry.quote: Because of the time-frame and effort involved, Google’s approach to research is iterative and usually involves writing production, or near-production, code from day one. Elaborate research prototypes are rarely created, since their development delays the launch of improved end-user services. Typically, a single team iteratively explores fundamental research ideas, develops and maintains the software, and helps operate the resulting Google services – all driven by real-world experience and concrete data.

entry.title: In Design, Empathy is Not Enough
entry.quote: Empathy is hot right now. It’s being posited as one of the key characteristics that sets designers apart. (As though we have a monopoly on it.) But empathy is only a stepping stone on the way to a more important place: understanding.

entry.title: Mission Control: A History of the Urban Dashboard
entry.quote: We know what rocket science looks like in the movies: a windowless bunker filled with blinking consoles, swivel chairs, and shirt-sleeved men in headsets nonchalantly relaying updates from “Houston” to outer space. Lately, that vision of Mission Control has taken over City Hall. NASA meets Copacabana

entry.title: Uber: The Big Data Company
entry.quote: I am no longer just a passenger or a fare. I am a big data goldmine and, in case you hadn’t noticed, Uber just broke out the pickaxes.
